sections.title: 5. Festival Types & Categories
paragraphs: Gaucho, wine, and European heritage festivals dominate.

sections.title: 6. Religious & Faith-Based Festivals
paragraphs: Religious events and Semana Santa are significant.

sections.title: 7. Music & Dance Festivals
paragraphs: Music and dance festivals run throughout the year.

sections.title: 8. Folk & Traditional Celebrations
paragraphs: Gaucho traditions are central to local identity.

sections.title: 9. Food & Gastronomy Festivals
paragraphs: Wine and grape festivals are signature events.

sections.title: 10. Carnival & Pre-Carnival Events
paragraphs: Porto Alegre hosts the main carnival celebrations.

sections.title: 11. Indigenous & Afro-Brazilian Festivals
paragraphs: Afro-Brazilian heritage is recognized in cultural events.

sections.title: 12. State & Municipal Holidays
paragraphs: Semana Farroupilha is a unique state celebration.

sections.title: 13. Festival History & Origins
paragraphs: Festivals reflect gaucho heritage and European immigration.

sections.title: 14. Cultural Significance & Symbolism
paragraphs: Events symbolize regional pride and rural tradition.

sections.title: 15. Cost & Accessibility
paragraphs: Most events are free; some are ticketed.

sections.title: 16. Where Festivals Take Place
paragraphs: Porto Alegre, Gramado, and Caxias do Sul are key hubs.

sections.title: 17. Best Time to Visit for Festivals
paragraphs: September for gaucho celebrations and December in Gramado.

sections.title: 18. Local Customs & Etiquette
paragraphs: Respect gaucho traditions and local customs.

sections.title: 19. Safety & Crowd Tips
paragraphs: Prepare for cooler weather during winter festivals.

sections.title: 20. Family-Friendly vs Adult-Oriented Festivals
paragraphs: Most festivals are family-friendly; nightlife is adult-oriented.

sections.title: 21. Festival Food, Drinks & Traditions
paragraphs: Try churrasco, chimarrão, and regional wines.
